portfolioDetailDescription:
Scheduling Autorun of Reports - Global Dashboard

CONTENTS

  1. Tim's Story
  2. Problem Space
  3. Research
  4. Ideation
  5. Prototyping
  6. Usability Testing
  7. Icon Concept

TIM'S STORY

Hello !
My name is Tim Smith. I am an IT administrator and this is my story.

I monitor all the data centres through single sign-on application called Unity Dashboard. It gives me health status and related reports of all servers, networks and storage systems.

For last three months, few server reports are not in good health and need continuous attention and remediation. This has made my life difficult as I need to run reports everytime I reach office.

I need a way to autorun reports and get it delivered directly to my team’s mailbox daily, weekly or monthly so that I can take necessary actions in advance.

PROBLEM STATEMENT

How Might We design an intuitive way to run the reports automatically at required intervals like daily, weekly or monthly.
The report outcomes should be emailed to the team.
Make the whole process of scheduling simple, lightweight and consistent.

PROBLEM SPACE

RESEARCH

PRIMARY RESEARCH

Multiple interactions with stakeholders and end users revealed useful insights about the context and the need of the scheduling autorun of reports.

Few insights were -

  • Need of scheduled reports to ease the monitoring task as it keeps users from manually running when it’s critical.

  • Need of notification on the next run/next update so that users don’t miss on the critical updates.

SECONDARY RESEARCH

Secondary research on implementation of schedulars in different scenarios was done and the study on the patterns available uncovered the findings mentioned below.

SECONDARY RESEARCH FINDINGS

1. One schedule per instance works best.
2. There are four fields to set the frequency -frequency type, specific frequencies, start time and end time.
3. Frequency selection options are hierarchically dependent.
4. . There could be almost unlimited combinations of scheduling frequencies are possible, so instead of trying to cater for all needs, it should focus on the primary scenario.

IDEATION

GENERATING IDEAS

Out of six different solution approaches, two ideas primarily came out.
1. Schedule of a report as an independent entity with all CRUD operations
2. Multiple schedules attached to a report with CRUD operations and a lifecycle.
3. Single schedule for each report with On/Off states.
4. Progressive disclosure for all scheduling options.

PROTOTYPING

INTERACTIVE WIREFRAMES

Quick idea sketches were translated into digital interactive interfaces for for testing and feedback. Sketch +invision mock-ups were also created for reviews.

Report Listing Page

The page has all the reports listed here which shows all the reports. Thegreen and grey represents scheduled and unscheduled reports respectively.

Report Instance of Server Inventory Report

The action items of a report includes the Schedule as an option.

Scheduled Dialog (Off)

The scedule option is by default off initially with disabled controls, and can be toggled to turn it on.

Recurrent option for Schedules

The repeat options reveal the corresponding fields later on selection using progressive disclosure method to keep it simple and minimal.

Weekly Repeat Options

Week has checkboxes to select days of the week to auto-run the report only on selected days.

Daily Repeat Options

No extra field is required for daily option, as it repeats sametime daily till it’s turned off.

Monthly Repeat Options

A confirmation is shown after save or update. Similar to daily, monthly functions the same and runs at same time every month.

Confirmation

A confirmation is shown after save or update. The saved schedule is visible below the report title with the icon.

USABILITY TESTING

PLANNING THE TEST

Aimed at uncovering the usability issues and validation of few key design decisions, the usability test was planned with 5 app concepts to be validated, corresponding tasks and few follow-up questions.

A quick usability tesing was carried out to validate the solution and few key design decisions.

Valuable Insights

The custom options for daily and weekly removed considering as edge cases.

Auto selected current timestamp/days are easier and gives cues of valid inputs.

The idea of having only one schedule at a time works well for simplicity.

A/B Testing

A/B Testing to validate the placement of icons and other options in the interface using Hubspot.com.

ICON CONCEPT

ICON & THE CONTEXT OF USAGE

Designed a new icon for report sceduling option with consistent visual language of Grommet design system.

3 States of the Icon

Icon in grey shows that there are no saved schedules for the report, however it can be scheduled.

Icon in green shows that there is a saved schedule for the reports.

No Icon represents that the reports do not have an option to be scheduled.

Designing e-commerce platform

Scholastic is the world's largest publishers, distributors of children's books and a leader in educational technology. In addition to some most popular book series like Harry Potter Series and The Hunger Games, the company is well known for its school book clubs, book fairs, classroom magazines and educational technology programs.

PROJECT GOALS

THE BACKGROUND

This one-year assignment was an initiative to ramp up the online sales and conversion. It also focussed on engaging customers and guiding them to buy products and subscribe to the services.
As an individual contributor I also led the team of three with one front-end developer and two graphic designers.

PROBLEM STATEMENT & CHALLENGES

Transforming a content intensive web portal into an ecommerce application for consumers, book-distributors and wholesale retailers.
The challenges are as follows -

DESIGN PROCESS

The project started with primary and exhaustive secondary research. All the information of this content intensive site was restructured. Then, the iterative prototyping was done followed by testing at the end of each iteration.



  1. User and Market Research
  2. Competition Analysis
  3. Information Architecture
  4. Wireframes & Prototypes
  5. Usability Testing

RESEARCH

Limited feasibility to user research, the secondary research was reliable on the analytics data. The data analytics was designed in order to understand the users and derive meaningful insights out of it.

COMPETITION ANALYSIS

The online presence and performance of competitors were evaluated on different usabiity, content and overall experience parameters. The data was consolidated then to extract the positive and negative experiences.

INFORMATION ARCHITECTURE

The information peices were first grouped at high level, then chunked in the defined groups and the taxonomy was created. Hybrid card sorting was used to define the high level of groups using optimalworkshop studies.

WIREFRAMES & PROTOTYPES

Interactive prototypes were created and tested. The iterative design appraoch refined the wireframes and improved the usability and experience.



Landing/Home page - Focused on products, catalogs and easy global search to quickly start buying titles.

FOCUS ON PRODUCTS

The information about products are segregated into categories and tagged with relevant subjects.
Sort and filter options are given to further focus on the user’s need and interest.

USABILITY TESTING

Key design decisions were exposed to usability testing and based on the outcomes, designs were revisited and iterated to improve the experience.

portfolioDescription: OpenDoors is a digital experience solution to build relationships with neighbours for happier and healthier lives. The solution doesn’t include only an app but it includes other external experiences as well. It inculcates the collaborative behaviour among people and encourages inclusive happiness and prosperity.
portfolioDetailDescription:
Strategies of Design Thinking Process have been adopted to understand the problem, potential users and the ecosystem around it. Afterwards the multiple options of solution were explored and later narrowed down to best feasible and viable solution.

The Challenge

Relationships are considered as one of the most complex conundrums in the world. Solving this indeed wasn't that simple too. Here are some of the challenges tackled in this design problem -

  • Understanding the complex ecosystem of human's interpersonal behaviour through research and brainstorming
  • Getting into the roots of the constraints that people have in order to build good relationships
  • Ideating & Designing the solution by combining both digital and non-digital experiences

Understanding users & The Context

A large idea wall helped in understanding the problem and the context more clearly and visualizing the big picture at once. Analyzing available opportunities and odds for building new relationships among people led to ideating and exploring new ways to bring people together(as shown in the image).

Empathize

Talking to people about connecting with people from diverse backgrounds gave valuable insights. Creating a persona ‘Ronit’ for the context and building scenarios around it using PIE tool brought the solution closer to reality and made it more pragmatic.

Persona Story – Ronit is a CA who has recently shifted to his new apartment and willing to connect to his neighbors but due to his tight work schedule he is not able to even meet people at his next-door.

Ideation

Ideation started with spinning the story around the provisional persona. It helped in considering the whole ecosystem together in broader sense. Moving ahead, the ideas of having these two important glues which can bring people together came out was – Activities & Initiatives
These are the activities, which can be accomplished online as well as offline to keep people closer even in cases of unmatched schedules or commitments.

Prototyping & Iteration

Sketching number of interface screens, solution ideas and multiple options refined the prototypes cumulatively. It also rectified the minor pitfalls like potential security issues and other feasibility constraints.

Sketches were translated into interactive prototypes using Axure and Sketch tools to create a more real prototype, which can be produced to the users for testing. Interactive Prototype in action can be seen here - Interactive Wires

portfolioTitle: Quick Service Restaurants Kiosk & Mobile App Design
portfolioDescription: This is an app to function on kiosk in Quick Service Restaurants and mobile phones to order food, pay and get the food in minimal time.
portfolioDetailDescription:
The project was an excellent example of customizing and implementing UX processes baased on project constraints such as timelines and agile requirements.

The Challenge

Eliminating the unnecessary elements from design and the whole interaction in order to get the minimal and easy-to-use app was a challenge. This was successfully tackled by a collaborative design approach, in which multiple solutions were thought by participants and the best feasible solution was chosen.

Brainstorming On Requirements & User Needs



Mulling over the requirements along with direct communication with customers illucidated the big picture of the whole system and the idea started taking a definitive shape.

Multiple inputs from other team members enriched the concepts to progress further in the right direction. The whole journey for users got conceptualized and the flow was designed.

Information Architecture

Considering this to be an app meant for mobiles devices and kiosks, the emphasis was on making the IA as shallow as possible. Since the prime objective of this app is to book an order in minimum possible time, the IA must have been very shallow facilitating an intuitive navigation.

Low Fidelity Concept Sketches

High Fidelity Wireframes

Sketching interfaces makes the concepts clearer and then taking it forward to create high fidelity wireframes specify the details of design and interaction patterns.

Sketches were translated into wireframes using Balsamiq, Visio and Powerpoint and produced with the UI element and behavior specifications.

Visual Designs

portfolioSubTitle: Revamping Rural Arts & Crafts in India
portfolioDescription: KalaSarthi symbolizes the force which drives the arts and crafts in rural India. With the objective of providing a sustainable livelihood to the rural artisans, KalaSarthi was born. It started a mission to take the Indian crafts market to a different level.
portfolioDetailDescription:
The project exemplified the perfect implementation and adoption of classical UX process starting from ground research, conceptualization till the visual design and prototyping.

The Challenge

Kalasarthi is our little endeavour in the direction which aims for sustainable income for indian artisans. We also wished to create a system to protect, preserve and promote Indian art & crafts. We strived to create a concept that would appeal to urban consumer while retaining the original essence. ‘KalaSarthi’ - kala means art and saarthi is the one who drives a cart. KalaSarthi symbolizes the force which drives the arts and crafts in rural India. It emphasizes on revival and growth of the culture that belongs to us and should not be lost.

Conceptualization & Strategy



Brainstorming sessions and number of discussions helped in shaping up the model for this idea, which started with a cause of helping indian artisans get a sustainable income and dignified lifestyle. The model emphasised on eliminating an existing channel of middlemen between end-consumers and the artisans.

The model, which could come up by setting a proper communication and flow among all the profiles are as follows -

Research

Survey, Direct User Interviews and Field Research was done to understand the needs of users. It captured the observed behaviors of the users and portrayed a clear picture of the ecosystem around it.

Analysis Through Concept Models & Profiles

TARGET POPULATION ANALYSIS

  • The objective of the website -
    • Preserve, protect and promote the art and craft of India
    • To ensure continuity of craft through sustainable income
    • Experimenting with new concepts and develop designs that appeal urban consumers while retaining the original essence
    • Encourage GenNext to continue the tradition and ensure their skills stay relevant and alive
    • Create cultural sensitivity in consumers; at an affordable price
  • The target users of this portal can be anyone and everyone. The portal on a large scale is to target the entire handicraftsector of the country. COnsidering the vast scope including artisans, designers, its difficult to accomodate all within the scope of the project.

    In Short, the prime objective of the portal at present can focus on developing a sustainable work model which favors artisans in their socio-economic upliftment. THrough the portal we intend to minimize the intermediate points in demand and supply chain which in turn would curb exploitation of both extremes.

High Fidelity Wireframes

Visual Designs

portfolioDescription: Its a very common situation among most of the travellers, who could not plan their travel in advance for some reason and end up with unavailability of their preffered mode/route of travel. Makemytrip facilitates this through routeplanner with a single end-to-end trip plan via different modes of travel and diferent alternate routes as per your choice and preferences. This description entails the story of designing routeplanner, which starts with research, followed by analysis, design, evaluation and prototype.
portfolioDetailDescription:
We dont do just booking... we truely make your trip pleasurable as per your convenience.

The Challenge

  • Conceptualisation of the routeplanner so as to work best in Indian context
  • Should be optimised for web and mobile devices
  • Presenting all relevant information on differently sized devices
  • Consistent with the other applications and their interactions

Research

The foundation of a robust design lies in research, for a quicker approach research has been kept limited to

  1. understanding the users
  2. understanding the context

The tools used in this research are -
  • User Research - Interviews & Survey through an online questionnaire
  • Market/Competition Research - Online study and analysis

The user research to improve the experience of routeplanner of makemytrip.com has been conducted over a small group of 15 people to understand their travel preferences and use the insights to strategize a new design for desktops and mobile devices. The objective of the research was to get clear insights regarding different attributes of travel behaviors, needs and preferences. The research also included the understanding of those untold stories of users’ needs which users might not have noticed or realized so far. The findings has been summarized here in detail.

Analysis

To inseminate the findings of research into design is more important than the research itself. In order to utilize the outcomes of the research, an exhaustive analysis has been carried out, which includes following activities -

  • Attribute mapping of user research data to define Persona
  • Storyboarding to depict a scenario more effectively
  • Navigational Modelling to define the structure

A simplest possible navigational model has been designed on the lines of the mental models of the users.
Home - routeplanner(search) - route options(search results) - booking - finish


Design Sketches & Wireframes

Prototype

Some snapshots of the prototype. Interactive prototype can be seen here - routeplanner in action.
